title-group.article-title: An energy analyzing method for the assessment and diagnosis of rub–impact fault in a rotor system

article-meta.aff: State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, People's Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Feiyun Cong, State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, No.800, Dongchuan Road, Shanghai 200240, People's Republic of China Email: congfeiyun@hotmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: An energy analyzing method called the Impact Energy Model (IEM) is introduced to assess and diagnose the rub–impact fault of a rotor system. The main purpose of the model is to indicate the probability of rub–impact or the severity level of the fault. Utilizing the nonlinear predictive energy, an effective quantitative evaluation index IEM is obtained from the model. Some work has been done elsewhere to partly demonstrate the IEM through experiments. In this paper we mainly discuss the variation of the IEM index with the speed ratio Ω at different levels of damping ratio ξ. The stagnation point is discussed in detail which is important to the assessment for the probability or severity of a rub–impact fault. The influence of dynamic stiffness is discussed which may affect the assessment result of the IEM. Furthermore, a sensitive area of the rotor operating system is presented. The result shows that this sensitive area provides a reference for the operation and design of a rotor system.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Rotating machinery is commonly used in our society for a wide range of energy conversion applications, such as electric power, mechanical power, fluid pumping, propulsion, ventilation and cooling, etc. (Zhang and Meng, 2006c). With the increasing development of science and technology, rotating machinery in modern industry is becoming more precise. Thus, the faults of the machinery are also becoming more difficult to identify (Lei et al., 2009). Because vibration signals carry a great deal of information representing the condition of the mechanical equipment, the vibration analysis is an oft-applied and most effective way of diagnosing the rotating machinery faults (An et al., 2009).

Rotor-to-stator rub is a serious malfunction in rotating machinery (Chu and Lu, 2005). It will cause very complicated vibration in a rotor system and is one of the reasons for the system instability. When it occurs, severe vibration will be induced in the equipment at the very least. What is worse, it will lead to the permanent bow to the shaft, and even the damage the whole shaft system. There are many of analyses of the performance for rub–impact faults. Choy and Padovan (1987) analyzed the effects of different system parameters on rubbing forces and transient responses of a rub–impact rotor system. Ehrich (1988) studied the cases of the rub–impact between the shaft and the bearing and the rub–impact between the rotor and the stator near supports at two ends of the Jeffcott rotor system. Zhang et al. (1998) analyzed the rub–impact fault caused by geometric asymmetry between the rotor and stator, and studied the grazing phenomenon of the single point rubbing in detail. Zhang, Meng and coworkers (Meng et al., 2009; Zhang and Meng, 2005, 2006a, 2006b, 2009; Zhang et al., 2005, 2008a, 2008b, 2009) have published a series of research on the nonlinear micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMSs), including stability, bifurcation and chaos. Also they presented a variety of detailed research on the influence of several nonlinear parameters on the rotor system.

As pointed out above, most of research for the nonlinear rub–impact phenomenon are focused on the stability and chaos analysis. Based on a previous work (Cong et al., 2011), this study mainly discusses the new mathematic analysis model (Impact Energy Model [IEM]) in theory. The relationship between the rotating speed and the severity of vibration is discussed for detailed research. The impact energy (IE) was proposed to reflect the severity of the rub–impact fault. The mathematic model gives a detailed discussion on the state of rub–impact according to the change of rotating speed.

The paper is organized as follows: in Section 2, a general mathematical model of rotor system is introduced. The stability of the mathematical model solution is discussed in detail. Then, in Section 3, the proposed model IEM is introduced for the assessment of rub–impact in a rotor system. The detail of the IEM is discussed in Section 4. In this section, stagnation point placement, response of the speed changing model with different damping ratio ξ, sensitive area of the rotor system for operating and designing are investigated in detail. In Section 5, several key points of the model are presented combined with the actual operating and designing situation. Finally, the conclusions of the paper are drawn.

sec.title: 2.1. Rub–impact forces analysis
sec.p:
Since the rub–impact process of the rotor is very complex and there are many influences involved, a simplified dynamic model called a Jeffcott rotor system with rub–impact is derived for simplicity and for extruding the main problems. As showed in Figure 1, the Jeffcott rotor consists of a massless shaft carrying a disk with mass m at the middle of the span. The stator deformation is approximated by a rigid casing supported by radial springs with stiffness of k while the stiffness of the rotor shaft is ks and the clearance between the rotor and the stator is denoted by u. The mass center of the rotor is located at a distance e from its geometrical center. We can also consider the rotor system having a single point mass with two degrees of freedom supported on a massless flexible shaft (see Figure 1). Figure 1.
Schematic diagram of the rotor system with rub–impact.

It is assumed that the heating effects due to friction can be ignored. The contact between the stator and rotor in the rotor system can be regarded as elastic impact because the time during rub–impact is very short compared with one complete period of rotating. Figure 2 shows the rub–impact rotor model under the above assumptions. In the figure, Fn is the radial impact force, Fr is the tangential rub force, φ is the inclination angle between the direction radius of the contact point and X-axis and ω is the angular rotating speed of the rotor system. Figure 2.
Schematic diagram of the rub and impact forces.

Assuming that the radial deformation of the stator is linear and the friction relationship between the rotor and the stator satisfies Coulomb friction laws. The rub and impact forces can then be given as (1){Fn=ks(u-δ)(u>δ)Fr=fFnFn=0Fr=0(u<δ) where u=X2+Y2 is the radial displacement of the rotor, ks is the radial stiffness of the stator, f is the friction coefficient between the rotor and the stator, and δ is an initial clearance between the rotor and the stator. The rub and impact forces can be written in X−Y coordinates as (2){FX=-Fncosϕ+FrsinϕFY=-Fnsinϕ-Frcosϕ
Combining equations (1) and (2), the rub–impact force can be written as (3){FXFY}=[-cosϕsinϕ-sinϕ-cosϕ]{FnFr}=-ks(u-δ)u[1-ff1]{XY}

sec.title: 2.2. The governing equations of motion
sec.p: According to the rub and impact forces analyses and barycenter motion theorem, when the rotor rubs the stator, the Jeffcott rotor system can be described by the following differential equation of motion: (4){mX··+cX·+kX+ks(u-δ)u(X-fY)=meω2cosωtmY··+cY·+kY+ks(u-δ)u(fX+Y)=meω2sinωt (u>δ) whereX·=dX/dt and Y·=dY/dt, X and Y are the displacements of the axes centers of the rotor in X and Y directions, respectively, m is the mass of the rotor, c is the damping coefficient, k is the stiffness coefficient; and e is the imbalance.
The non-dimensional variables are defined as
Then equation (4) can be further rewritten in the following non-dimensional form: (5){x··+2ξx·+x+β(1-1v)(x-fy)=ρΩ2cosΩτy··+2ξy·+y+β(1-1v)(fx+y)=ρΩ2sinΩτ (v>1)
Without rubbing against the stator, the governing equation of motion can be formulated as (6){x··+2ξx·+x=ρΩ2cosΩτy··+2ξy·+y=ρΩ2sinΩτ (v≤1)

sec.title: 2.3. Stability of the rub–impact model
sec.p: According to the equation solution theory, we assume that both equations (5) and (6) have a steady-state periodic solution as follows: (7){x=Acos(Ωτ+ϕ)y=Asin(Ωτ+ϕ)
Then we substitute equation (7) into the governing equation (6). The amplitude and the phase angle of the solution can be yielded by (8){A=ρΩ2(1-Ω2)+4ξ2Ω2tanϕ=-2ξΩ1-Ω2

Owing to the existence of the stator, the solution of equation (6) is eligible only when its amplitude A satisfies A≤1. The parameter equation in the parameter space where the solution exists can then be given by (9)(ρ2-1)Ω4+2(1-2ξ2)Ω2-1≤0

Two real roots Ω1 and Ω2 (Ω1 < Ω2) can be derived by solving equation (9) if the other parameters are considered to be constant. The steady-state periodic solutions of the rotor system (6) will exist only between Ω1 and Ω2 in the parameter regions, while for the governing equation (5) we can obtain its solution by substituting equation (7) into equation (5) and a polynomial of the amplitude A can be given by (10)a2A2+a1A+a0=0 where a2=Ω4+(4ξ2-2-2β)Ω2+4ξβfΩ +(1+2β+β2+β2f2)a1=2βΩ2-4ξβfΩ+(-2β-2β2-2β2f2)a0=-ρ2Ω4+β2+β2f2
The saddle-node bifurcation condition can be obtained by simplifying with respect to A: (11)a1 2-4a0a2=0

The stability of the steady-state periodic solutions of equations (5) and (6) is discussed in detail in this study. One main purpose of this discussion is that for the physical systems, only stable solutions reflect the system response which can really happen (Jiang and Ulbrich, 2001). First we introduce x1 = x, x2 = y, x3=x·, x4=y·, then we can rewrite the governing equations of motion (5) and (6) as follows: (12){x·1=x3x·2=x4x·3=-2ξx3-x1-Θ (v-1v )(x1-fx2)+ρΩ2cosΩτx·4=-2ξx4-x2-Θ (v-1v )(fx1+x2)+ρΩ2sinΩτ where Θ is the Heaviside function (13)Θ={1 (x1 2+x2 2 )1/2>δ0 (x1 2+x2 2 )1/2≤δ

Denoting state vector variables X={x1,x2,x3,x4}T, equation (12) can be rewritten as (14)X·=g(X,τ)=BX+F(X,τ) where B=[00100001-10-2ξ00-10-2ξ] F(X,τ)={00-Θ(v-1v)(x1-fx2)+ρΩ2cosΩτ-Θ(v-1v)(fx1+x2)+ρΩ2sinΩτ}

For simplicity, introducing the steady-state periodic solution in the following form (15){x0(τ)=Acos(Ωτ+ϕ)=Acosθy0(τ)=Asin(Ωτ+ϕ)=Asinθ where A is defined by equations (8) and (10), and its value can be obtained by these two equations for the solutions.

Linearizing equation (10) around solution (15): (16)δX·=Lg|x=x0 δX=JδX where L is a derivative operator, J is the Jacobian matrix and δX is a perturbation of the steady-state periodic solution X0 = (X0,Y0,X10,Y10). The stability of solution δX is determined by the Eigenvalues of J and it also reflects the stability of solution X0 in equation (14). Therefore, we only need to analyze the stability of the corresponding solution of (16) in order to determine the stability of the steady-state periodic solutions of Equation (14) and thus, the stability of the solutions of the linear equations (5) and (6).

The Jacobian matrix about the linear steady-state periodic solution, corresponding to the case of Θ = 0 in equation (14), is just matrix B and the associated characteristic equation has the form (17)λ4+4ξλ3+(2+4ξ2)λ2+4ξλ+1=0
From the Routh–Hurwitz conditions, it is known that the linear steady-state solution of equation (6) is stable if and only if (18)4ξ2+ξ>0

If condition (18) comes into existence at any condition (ξ < 0), the corresponding steady-state periodic solutions are stable. However, the rotor will rub with the stator due to the existence of the stator when the vibration amplitude is beyond the clearance. When rub between the rotor and the stator happens, the motion of the rotor system will then be governed by equation (5).

When Θ = 1, the solutions of equation (5) are the nonlinear periodic solutions, the Jacobian matrix J can be rewritten as (19)J=[00100001-2+1A(1-cos2θ+fsinθcosθ)f-1A(f-fsin2θ+sinθcosθ)-2ξ0-f+1A(f-fcos2θ-sinθcosθ)-2+1A(1-sin2θ-fsinθcosθ)0-2ξ]

The Jacobian matrix J is considered to be periodic time-dependent from equation (19). The governing equation of motion (5) is non-autonomous system and cannot be used to determine the stability of the system directly. Therefore, introducing non-singular linear transformation: (20)δX=LδU where T is the transformation matrix T=[cosθ-sinθ00sinθcosθ0000cosθ-sinθ00sinθcosθ]
Substituting equation (20) into (16) then yields (21)δU·=JcδU where Jc=T-1(JT-T·) and Jc can be derived as (22)Jc=[0Ω10-Ω001-2f(1-1A)-2ξ0-f-2+1A-Ω-2ξ]

It can be seen from equation (22) that the matrix Jc is time independent. The stability of the solution δU and the solutions of equation (16) can be determined by the sign of the real parts of the eigenvalues of the matrix Jc. The corresponding characteristic equation satisfies |Jc −λI| = 0. Using the Laplace expansion formula of partitioned matrix, the associated characteristic equation can be obtained (23)c4λ4+c3λ3+c2λ2+c1λ+c0=0 where {c4=1c3=4ξc2=2Ω2+4ξ2-1A+4c1=4ξΩ2+(4f-2Af)Ω+8ξ-2Aξc0=Ω4+(4ξ2+1A-4)+(4fξ-2Afξ)Ω +(f2-2Af2-2A+4)

The values of these coefficients are functions of the amplitude A and the Routh–Hurwitz criteria can be adopted to judge the stability of nonlinear steady-state periodic solutions of equation (14). However, we are not only interested in the stability of the given solutions but also in the stability regions of the parameter space. From the point view of the bifurcation theory, the bifurcation boundaries of the analyzed solutions are of interest.
In this case, if there is one zero eigenvalue of the Jacobian matrix Jc and the condition corresponds to c0 = 0, namely (24)c0=Ω4+ (4ξ2+1A-4 )+ (4fξ-2Afξ )Ω + (f2-2Af2-2A+4 )=0

For any amplitude A, the relationship between Ω and the other relative parameters can be obtained by combining equations (10) and (24). We can then determine the condition in the parameter space where the saddle-node bifurcation of the steady-state periodic solutions of the rotor system occurs. According to the Hopf bifurcation theorem, Hopf bifurcation of the solutions will appear if there is one pair of conjugate purely imaginary eigenvalues. Assuming the eigenvalues satisfy λ = ±ωv and substituting it into equation (23) yields (25)c1 2-c1c2c3+c0c3 2=0

Substituting c0 ∼ c3 in equation (23) into equation (25) and combining equation (10), the polynomial of Ω can be obtained which can be used to determine the Hopf bifurcation condition of the nonlinear solutions in the parameter space.

sec.title: 3. Impact to energy model for rub–impact
sec.p: For rotating machinery, there are many theory literatures discussing the rub–impact fault of the shaft in the past few decades. However, most of this research has focused on the stability, bifurcation and chaos of the rotating machinery (Chu and Zhang, 1997, 1998; Jiang and Ulbrich, 2001; Meng et al., 2009; Pavlovskaia et al., 2004; Roques et al., 2010; Zhang and Meng, 2006b, 2006c; Zhang et al., 2008b). Few discussions have been presented on the severity of rub–impact. In this study, a new analyzing method based on the predictive impact energy of the rotating rotor is proposed. We call it the IEM which describes the rub–impact fault according the index of impact energy.
According to equation (6), we can obtain the equation solution as equation (8) shows. Then rewrite the solution of A in equation (8) (26)A=ρ (1Ω )4+ (4ξ2-2 ) (1Ω )2+1
From this equation, a parameter state space can be observed which is about Ω, ξ. For the variable Ω, a stagnation point can be acquired which is shown as follows (27)Ω=11-2ξ2

We can obtain different amplitudes A with the parameter Ω and ξ changing. However, this analysis process is based on the precondition that the rotor does not contact with the stator. In our IEM, first we assume that the stator does not exist or does not contact with the rotor. So the analysis process of equations (26) and (27) can meet the actual condition of the rotating system. Based on this assumption, the amplitude A can be obtained from equation (26) and is contrasted with the initial clearance δ. As Figure 3 shows, ΔA = A – δ, which shows that rub–impact will occur in the rotor system. The ΔA can reflect the energy of the impact. According to the Hooke theorem and the energy conservation law, the IE can be calculated by the following equation (28)E=12mkx2 Figure 3.
Schematic diagram of the Impact Energy Model.
Thus, we obtain the impact energy IE (29)IE=12mk(A2-δ2)=12mk(2ΔAδ+ΔA2)

Because we can obtain the amplitude A from equation (26), substitute it into equation (29). The IE value can be obtained according to the following equation (30)IE=12mk(ρ2 (1Ω )4+ (4ξ2-2 ) (1Ω )2+1-δ2)

From equation (30) we can observe that the IE index has a close relationship with the parameter Ω and ξ. In the next section, we give a detailed discussion on the two main effect factors (speed ratio Ω and damping ratio ξ). According to the analysis of the effect factors, we can obtain the information about the probability or severity of a rub–impact fault. If the A solution is larger than the initial clearance δ, the rub–impact will occur and the larger A is, the more severe the system fault will be. However, because of the existence of some other factors such as misalignment (Huang et al., 2010), sliding whirl (Jiang and Ulbrich, 2001), random disturbance and so on, a slight rub–impact fault may also occur even when the equation solution A is not larger than δ. So we utilize a fault probability concept to explain the influence of the parameter (the larger the amplitude A, the higher the probability of rub–impact). Several limiting conditions must be emphasized for the IEM:
The speed ratio Ω should be limited in a low range. Less than 2 may be appropriate.
The rotor system can be considered to be a Jeffcott rotor system which has a single point mass with two degrees of freedom supported on a massless flexible shaft.
The duration of the impact between the rotor and stator should be short enough so that the contact can be regarded as elastic collision.
The stability character of the system has been detail discussed by Zhang and Meng (2006c). In the suggestion in item (1), the stability of the IEM is similar to that of Zhang and Meng (2006c).
The heating effects are ignored.

sec.title: 4. Detailed analysis of the effect of speed on the IEM
sec.p: In the actual rotor system, speed factor is always the most changeable factor. So in this section, we discuss the influence of parameters with the speed ratio Ω as the mainline. From equation (26) we can obtain the influencing critical point which will change the monotonicity of the equation by following equation: (31)α=-4ξ2-22=1-2ξ2=0

Then the influencing critical point is calculated to be ξ=22. If ξ≥22, the amplitude A will continuously increase as the speed ratio Ω increases, while if ξ<22, the amplitude A will first increase with the speed ratio Ω and then decrease if Ω becomes larger than the stagnation point observed by equation (27). Figure 4 shows the variety of the amplitude with the speed ratio Ω at different damping ratio point. Figure 4(a) represents the state where ξ = 0.2, while ξ = 0.8 in Figure 4(b). From the figure we can see that (a) and (b) represent the two states of the monotonicity. Figure 4(a) shows that the amplitude will increase with the speed ratio Ω first and then decrease when Ω becomes larger than the stagnation point. In Figure 4(b), the amplitude will always increase with the speed ratio Ω. Figure 4
(a). Speed control of figure for the amplitude with ξ = 0.2. (b) Speed control of figure for the amplitude with ξ = 0.8.

In the IEM, IE is the main assessment index to obtain the information about the probability or severity of rub–impact fault. From equation (29) it is obvious that IE is directly related with amplitude A. Considering that the arguments including m, k and δ are constant for one certain rotor system, we propose another index obtained by equation (32). Using the index IEM we can get the detailed change process of the impact energy: (32)IEM=2IEmk+δ2

sec.title: 4.1. Stagnation point of the IEM
sec.p:
Equation (27) shows the equation of the stagnation point achieving method. From the equation, one critical point can be obtained which is shown in equation (31). Figure 5 shows the stagnation point placement’s changing with the change of Ω and ξ. From the figure we can see that if the damping ratio is larger than22, the stagnation point will be smaller than zero. Because the speed ratio Ω > 0, the amplitude A will continuously raise as Ω increases. If the damping ratio is smaller than22, the stagnation point placement on the axis of the speed ratio Ω will shift right with the increase of damping ratio ξ. Furthermore, the increasing rate of stagnation point placement on the axis of speed ratio Ω becomes larger with the increase of the damping ratio ξ. It is obvious that the placement of the stagnation point is important to the analysis of the system response. From Figure 5 we can also obtain that the position is very sensitive around the influencing critical point ξ = 22 which is crucial for the system response analysis in actual systems. Figure 5.
the stagnation point placement’s changing as Ω and ξ changes.

sec.title: 4.2. Response of the IEM for ξ >22
sec.p:
It has been pointed out in Section 0 that when the damping ratio ξ >22, the amplitude A will continuously rise as Ω increases. Figure 6 shows the expression of the IEM index with different damping ratio ξ (in the range of ξ >22). From the figure, three key points can be observed: (1) the IEM index increases with the increasing the speed ratio Ω. That means that the probability or severity of a rub–impact fault will increase as Ω rises. (2) The increasing rate of IEM is different as the damping ratio ξ changes. As the damping ratio increases from 0.7 to 1.5, the increasing rate of IEM becomes lower and lower. (3) If ξ is close to the crucial point, the increasing rate will be high at first and then turn to lower gradually. Figure 6.
the expression of IEM index with ξ = 0.7, 0.9, 1.2, 1.5 respectively.

sec.title: 4.3. Response of the IEM for ξ < 22
sec.p:
As there is a stagnation point in the analysis of IEM, the expression of the IEM will be more complicated than the station of ξ in Section 0. Figure 7 shows the IEM expression with the damping ratio ξ = 0.03, 0.07, 0.09, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, respectively. From this figure, we can see that: (1) the IEM index of each station experiences a process of first increasing and then decreasing, and reach its maximum value at the stagnation point; (2) the entire diagram of IEM seems ‘slenderer’ if the damping ratio ξ becomes smaller; (3) the magnitude of IEM will become very large if ξ is small enough. Comparing the diagram of ξ = 0.03 with that of ξ = 0.07, we can obtain that the maximum IEM is a factor of five different between them. However, on the other hand, if the damping ratio ξ is small, the stagnation point is very close to the fundamental frequency. In actual operation, we always prevent the rotor from performing in the fundamental frequency, which also prevents the system from staying in the stagnation point (maximum value point). Figure 7.
the expression of IEM index with ξ = 0.03, 0.07, 0.09, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6 respectively.

sec.title: 4.4. Joint distribution of Ω, ξ and IEM for the IEM
sec.p:
Figure 8 shows the joint distribution of Ω, ξ and IEM for the IEM. In order to explain the local details of the distribution, we intercept the figure by cutting off the part where IEM is larger than 5. From the figure, we can see that there is a sensitive area where Ω is in about 0.6–1.6 and ξ in 0–0.5. We give a detailed discussion of the influence of the parameters combined with rub–impact fault in the next section. Figure 8.
Joint distribution of Ω, ξ and IEM for the Impact Energy Model.

sec.title: 5.1. Main activity of the IEM
sec.p: From Figure 5 we can see the variation of the stagnation point placement with ξ and Ω. It is obvious that the placement of the stagnation point is important in the analysis of the speed influence. If ξ is small, for example smaller than 0.2 where the stagnation point is at Ω = 1.05 (close to the fundamental frequency), we can see that the probability of rub–impact will decrease after we operate the rotor system to speed up over the critical speed. However, if larger, for example larger than 0.4 where the stagnation point is higher than Ω = 1.21, attention is also needed even when the speed overtakes the critical speed because according to the IEM, the IEM index will increase until the speed ratio reaches the stagnation point.

According to Figure 8, a sensitive area of a rotor system can be obtained. Using this sensitive area distribution, we can effectively prevent the rotor system from running in this area or speed up over this area as quickly as possible. Furthermore, considering the sensitive area, we can make use of it to help design a rotor system. For example, if the system is discovered to work in the sensitive area after finishing the design of the system, we can come back to change the parameters of the rotor system according to Figure 8. From this we can see that this IEM is practical to both the normal operation of and design of a rotor system.

sec.title: 5.2. Influence of dynamic stiffness
sec.p:
Chu and Lu (2007) studied the stiffening effect of the rotor during the rotor-to-stator rub in a rotor system. In their study, the effect of stiffness during the rub–impact is discussed in detail and validated by experiment. It is stated that the transient stiffness will increase with the rub–impact aggravating. The change of this dynamic stiffness k can affect the rub–impact state which is assessed by the IEM. Figure 9 shows the relation of the stiffness k and damping ratio ξ. One main point can be made that the damping ratio ξ will decrease as the stiffness k increases. Table 1 shows the influencing process of the dynamic stiffness to the IEM assessment result. In the increasing process in which the speed ratio is smaller than the critical speed, the severity of the rub–impact fault will increase as the rotating speed increases. Then the stiffness k and damping ratio ξ will increase and decrease, respectively. According to the joint distribution shown in Figure 8, the assessment index IEM will increase which shows that the rub–impact fault will be aggravated. In this process, the influence of dynamic stiffness is described as fault depravation. In the decreasing process, the analyzing method is the same as in the previous stage. The result shows that it will accelerate system stability. In all, we can describe the dynamic stiffness influence as a ‘push’ action. It will more or less ‘push’ the IEM assessment result. Figure 9.
The change of damping ratio ξ with stiffness k. Table 1.
Influence of dynamic stiffness on the rub–impact
State Severity of rub–impact Stiffness k Damping ratio ξ IEM index Severity trend of rub–impact
Increase process ↑ ↑ ↓ ↑ ↑
Decrease process ↓ ↓ ↑ ↓ ↓

sec.title: 5.3. Other influence to IEM
sec.p: In equation (26), the parameter ρ is an assistant influencing factor. It is proportional to the vibration amplitude A. According to its definition, it is directly related to the imbalance mass m, so its increase will influence the increase of IEM. In the actual operation of a rotor system, a decrease in the imbalance mass m will reduce the probability of rub–impact fault.

As for the large magnitude of IEM in the stagnation point problem, it is obvious that the stagnation point is very close to the fundamental frequency where we will prevent the system from working in actual operation. On the other hand, for one existing rotor system, all of the intrinsic parameters are constant. So, in the running state of the system, our main attention is focused on the speed influence on the probability of rub–impact.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: A speed change-based IEM is introduced to analyze the rub–impact fault of rotor system. An IEM index obtained from the model is adopted to assess the probability or severity of rub–impact fault. Based on our previous work (Cong et al., 2011), the study mainly discussed the changing of the IEM index with the speed ratio Ω at different level of damping ratio ξ. The stagnation point is discussed which is important to the assessment for the probability or severity of rub–impact fault. In the study, one case is emphasized that when the stagnation placement is far from the fundamental frequency point, more attention is needed until the speed exceeds the stagnation in the speed-up process of a rotor system. Furthermore, according to the analysis of the IEM, a sensitive area is presented to show the system response to the rub–impact fault assessment. The results are of great significance to the state assessment and fault diagnosis of a rotor system. They provide a reference for the operation and design of a rotor system.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The research is supported by the National Natural Science Foundation (approved grant numbers 50875162 and 51035007) and the National High Technology Research and Development Program of China (863 Program, grant number 2006AA04Z175).

ChuFLuW (2005) Experimental observation of nonlinear vibrations in a rub–impact rotor system. The Journal of Sound and Vibration 283: 621–643.
ChuFLuW (2007) Stiffening effect of the rotor during the rotor-to-stator rub in a rotating machine. The Journal of Sound and Vibration 308: 758–766.
ChuFZhangZ (1997) Periodic, quasi-periodic and chaotic vibrations of a rub–impact rotor system supported on oil film bearings. International Journal of Engineering Science 35: 963–973.
ChuFZhangZ (1998) Bifurcation and chaos in a rub–impact Jeffcott rotor system. The Journal of Sound and Vibration 210: 1–18.
